<A name='151'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Human
    Resources&#160;&#038; Compensation Committee</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee is responsible for ensuring that
    Agrium&#146;s executive compensation policies and programs are
    competitive in the markets in which Agrium competes for human
    resources and that they reflect the long-term interests of the
    Corporation and its Shareholders. Details with respect to the
    HR&#038;C Committee&#146;s Charter and mandate, its 2009
    accomplishments and key activities, its independence from
    management and other criteria for HR&#038;C Committee membership
    are set out in &#147;Section&#160;Three: Corporate
    Governance&#160;&#151; Committees of the Board of
    Directors&#160;&#151; Human Resources&#160;&#038; Compensation
    Committee&#148; (above). Details with respect to the HR&#038;C
    Committee&#146;s oversight of and role in the compensation
    process are set out under the heading &#147;Compensation
    Process&#148; (below).
</DIV>

<A name='152'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Agrium&#146;s
    Business</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    With annual sales of $9.3-billion in 2009 (as compared to
    $10.3-billion in 2008), Agrium is a leading agricultural
    products and services organization, a global producer and
    wholesale marketer of nutrients for agricultural and industrial
    markets and we operate and report our business through three
    strategic business units:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The <B>Retail Business Unit</B>, with net sales of $6.2-billion
    in 2009 (as compared to $5.5-billion in 2008), is the largest
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">direct-to-grower</FONT>
    distributor of crop nutrients, crop protection products and seed
    in the U.S.&#160;This includes significant retail operations in
    Canada and Argentina, as well as farm centers in Uruguay and
    Chile. Agrium&#146;s 2008 acquisition of UAP significantly
    expanded the number of retail farm centers and
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    38
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    dramatically increased the size of the seed and crop protection
    product business. As of January 2010, Agrium operated 826 retail
    centers, 37 terminals and 18 distribution centers in North and
    South America.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The <B>Wholesale Business Unit</B>, with net sales of
    $3.0-billion in 2009 (as compared to $4.7-billion in 2008),
    produces, markets and distributes nitrogen, phosphate and potash
    for agricultural and industrial customers around the world. Our
    facilities, operations and investments are located in Canada,
    the U.S., Argentina, Egypt and Europe. Agrium has production
    capacity of 8.4&#160;million tonnes of the primary crop
    nutrients, which includes nitrogen, potash, phosphate and
    sulphate crop nutrient products, representing about
    3&#160;percent of global capacity. In addition, we marketed
    2.7&#160;million tonnes of crop nutrient products purchased for
    resale through our extensive distribution system in North and
    South America as well as Europe.
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The <B>Advanced Technologies Business Unit</B>, with net sales
    of $304-million in 2009 (as compared to
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">$352-million</FONT>
    in 2008), is a leader in developing and marketing
    controlled-release nutrient technologies that offer customers
    economic value and environmental advantages. These products are
    used in broad-based agriculture, specialty agriculture,
    professional turf, horticulture and consumer lawn and garden
    markets worldwide. In the U.S.&#160;and Canada, we are
    successfully marketing our controlled-release products for
    commodity crops such as corn, wheat and potatoes.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition, a variety of corporate functions are included in a
    fourth non-operating Corporate Business Unit that provides
    support and services to the three strategic business units.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    As of December&#160;31, 2009, Agrium employed approximately
    11,200&#160;people worldwide. Over the past few years, Agrium
    has experienced, and continues to experience, exceptional
    growth. For more information about Agrium&#146;s business and
    operations please see our Annual Information Form dated
    February&#160;25, 2010 and filed under the Corporation&#146;s
    profile on SEDAR (at www.sedar.com) and EDGAR (at
    www.sec.gov/edgar.shtml).
</DIV>

<A name='153'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Principles/Objectives
    of Compensation Program</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The objectives of Agrium&#146;s compensation program are to:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    attract and retain the most talented people by providing
    competitive total compensation;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    motivate and reward employees to achieve Agrium&#146;s measures
    of success by &#147;paying for performance&#148; and rewarding
    demonstrated behaviours that reinforce Agrium&#146;s values and
    help the Corporation deliver on its corporate objectives,
    including:
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="8%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="90%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    shareholder return, as measured by stock price appreciation plus
    dividends on a reinvested basis,
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    corporate and business unit financial performance, including
    (i)&#160;earnings per share, (ii)&#160;cash flow,
    (iii)&#160;disciplined investment, and (iv)&#160;certification
    of internal controls,
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    company strategy achievements, including (i)&#160;industry
    leadership growth, (ii)&#160;employee health and safety, and
    (iii)&#160;creation and sustenance of high performance
    culture,&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    individual performance focused on financial and operational
    measures;
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="94%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    promote adherence to high ethical, environmental and health and
    safety standards;
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    provide flexibility so that the compensation program is
    responsive to changes in the marketplace, organization and
    economic conditions;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    &#149;&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    protect Shareholder interests and ensure that the interests of
    leaders are aligned with those of Shareholders.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<A name='154'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Compensation
    Program Design</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The total compensation mix and performance-based compensation
    opportunities are based on our compensation objectives and
    designed to motivate employees to achieve the Corporation&#146;s
    strategic plan and overall goals of superior total Shareholder
    return through revenue growth, EBITDA growth, superior returns
    on invested capital and a balanced portfolio of products, assets
    and geographies.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">2009
    Compensation Mix</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Standard compensation arrangements for Agrium&#146;s senior
    executives are composed of the following elements, which are
    linked to Agrium&#146;s compensation and corporate objectives as
    follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 15pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE border="0" width="100%" align="center" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 7pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
<!-- Table Width Row BEGIN -->
<TR style="font-size: 1pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD width="14%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=01 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="42%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=02 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="18%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=03 type=maindata -->
    <TD width="2%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=gutter -->
    <TD width="21%">&nbsp;</TD>	<!-- colindex=04 type=maindata -->
</TR>
<!-- Table Width Row END -->
<!-- TableOutputHead -->

<TD>
&nbsp;

<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Link to Corporate<BR>
    </B>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    <B>Compensation Element</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Description</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Objectives</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Objectives</B>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="line-height: 5pt; font-size: 1pt">
<TD>&nbsp;
</TD>

<!-- TableOutputBody -->
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Standard Compensation</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Base Salary</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Senior executives (including each NEO) are paid a pre-determined
    base salary. Salary is a market-competitive, fixed level of
    annual compensation.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Attract and Retain<BR>
    <BR>
    Reward
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Competitive pay ensures access to talented employees necessary
    to achieve corporate objectives. Yearly salary review is based
    on attainment of NEO goals, specifically linked to corporate
    objectives.  See &#147;Determining Actual Compensation&#148;
    (below).
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    Benefits and Perks
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Senior executives (including NEOs) are entitled to standard health benefits on substantially the same terms as are available to employees under a shared cost flexible benefits program. <BR><BR>The Corporation provides perks to certain senior executives (including the NEOs), which include automobile allowances, parking and financial planning.<BR><BR>In addition, officers are entitled to limited benefits on termination of employment, as described under &#147;2009 Executive Compensation: Tables and Narrative&#160;&#151; Termination and Change of Control Benefits&#148; (below).</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Attract and Retain
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Competitive benefits and perks ensure access to talented
    employees necessary to achieve corporate objectives.  In
    addition, appropriate perks facilitate focus on job performance.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Retirement Arrangements</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Senior executives (including NEOs) participate in defined contribution plans (the registered DC Plan for Canadian executives and the qualified 401(k) Plan for U.S. executives), pursuant to which the Corporation and participants contribute a percentage of eligible base salary.<BR><BR>Designated executives (including the NEOs) are also members of the defined benefit supplemental executive retirement plans (the Canadian DB SERP for Canadian executives and the U.S. DB SERP for U.S. executives), pursuant to which designated executives receive a supplemental defined benefit pension based on eligible earnings and years of service as a designated executive.<BR><BR>See &#147;2009 Executive Compensation: Tables and Narrative&#160;&#151; Pension Plan Benefits&#148; for detailed descriptions of the DC Plan, the 401(k) Plan, the Canadian DB SERP and the U.S. DB SERP.</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Attract and Retain
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 6pt">Competitive retirement arrangements
    ensure access to talented employees necessary to achieve
    corporate objectives.
    </FONT>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">

&nbsp;
</TD>

&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">

&nbsp;

<TD colspan="5" valign="top">

    operational and financial measures and align pay with
    performance.

<TD colspan="3" valign="top">

    <B>Profit Sharing Plan</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Certain employees (including the NEOs) are eligible to
    participate in the profit sharing plan (the &#147;<B>Profit
    Sharing Plan</B>&#148;), which provides annual incentive
    compensation up to a predetermined percentage of each
    employee&#146;s base salary if EBITDA targets are met by the
    Corporation.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Motivate and Reward
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
The Profit Sharing Plan focuses on the achievement of EBITDA targets. <BR><BR>See &#147;Determining Actual Compensation&#148; (below) for details regarding 2009 EBITDA targets.
</DIV>
</TD>

<!-- TableOutputBody -->
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Performance Recognition Plan</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Certain Agrium Corporate and Wholesale employees (including all
    NEOs) participate in the performance recognition plan (the
    &#147;<B>Performance Recognition Plan</B>&#148;), which provides
    annual incentive compensation up to a predetermined percentage
    of each employee&#146;s base salary if key performance measures
    and individual performance goals are met. The Performance
    Recognition Plan is designed to recognize the cyclical nature of
    the industry and balances management&#146;s focus on the
    achievement of critical corporate and business unit financial
    metrics, operating metrics and the achievement of longer term
    objectives linked to the annual business plan and the longer
    term business strategy.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Motivate and Reward
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
The Performance Recognition Plan focuses on the achievement of objectives at the corporate, business unit and individual level, including achievement of Agrium&#146;s key performance indicators (&#147;<B>KPIs</B>&#148;). <BR><BR>See &#147;Determining Actual Compensation&#148; (below) for a discussion of KPIs.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Retail Incentive Plan</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Retail Business Unit employees (including senior executives of the Retail Business Units, but excluding the President of the Retail Business Unit) are eligible to participate in the Retail Incentive Plan (the &#147;<B>Retail Plan</B>&#148;), which provides access to an annual incentive of up to a predetermined percentage of the employee&#146;s salary based on the achievement of local, regional and Business Unit EBIT targets and Business Unit KPI targets.<BR><BR><B>None of the NEOs are eligible to participate in the Retail Plan. </B>Accordingly, further information with respect to the Retail Plan has not been included in the CD&#038;A.</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Motivate and Reward
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The Retail Plan focuses on EBIT targets and achievement of
    Business Unit KPIs.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Advanced Technologies Incentive Plan</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Advanced Technologies Business Unit employees (including senior executives of the Advanced Technologies Business Unit, but excluding the President of the Advanced Technologies Business Unit) are eligible to participate in the Advanced Technologies Incentive Plan (the &#147;<B>AAT Plan</B>&#148;), which provides access to an annual incentive of up to a predetermined percentage of the employee&#146;s salary based on the achievement of local, regional and Business Unit targets and Business Unit KPI targets. <BR><BR><B>None of the NEOs are eligible to participate in the AAT Plan. </B>Accordingly, further information with respect to the AAT Plan has not been included in the CD&#038;A.</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Motivate and Reward
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The AAT Plan focuses on achieving business unit targets measured
    by return on investment capital and is funded based on a share
    of EBITDA.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Long-Term Incentives</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD colspan="5" valign="top">
    The Corporation believes that the PSU Plan (defined below) and
    the Stock Option Plan (defined below) (i)&#160;provide for a
    balanced long-term incentive approach that recognizes the
    cyclical nature of the business, (ii)&#160;provide a better
    total alignment with Shareholder interests and
    (iii)&#160;facilitate long-term equity ownership.
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Stock Options and Tandem SARs</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Certain employees (including NEOs) are eligible to participate in the Stock Option and Tandem SAR Plan (the &#147;<B>Stock Option Plan</B>&#148;). The Corporation may grant options to purchase Common Shares at the closing price on the day preceding the grant. Vesting of options is determined by the Board at the time of grant; although, options generally vest in 25% increments over four years and expire ten years after the date of grant. <BR><BR>Commencing in 2004, Agrium made grants of stock options in tandem with stock appreciation rights (&#147;<B>SARs</B>&#148;) to eligible Canadian employees. Option holders have the right to surrender vested stock options back to the Corporation in exchange for a cash payment from the Corporation equal to the option gain that would have otherwise been realized. This assists in the management of Shareholder dilution related to the Stock Option Plan and provides increased transparency through variable accounting for the purposes of expensing stock options.<BR><BR>See <B>Sc
hedule &#147;E&#148; </B>for a detailed description of the Stock Option Plan.</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Attract and Retain<BR>
    <BR>
    Motivate<BR>
    <BR>
    Align executive and Shareholder interests
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Competitive stock option grants ensure access to talented employees necessary to achieve corporate objectives. <BR><BR>Motivates employees to achieve corporate goals and improve value of Common Shares, as stock options gain value only if share price increases over grant price. <BR><BR>Encourages sustained, long-term growth by linking portion of compensation to long-term company performance.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Compensation<BR>
    </B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Link to Corporate<BR>
    </B>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom" align="center">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="bottom">
    <B>Compensation Element</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Description</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Objectives</B>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="center" valign="bottom">
    <B>Objectives</B>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="line-height: 5pt; font-size: 1pt">
<TD>&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<!-- TableOutputBody -->
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Stock Appreciation Rights</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Certain employees (including NEOs) who are not residents of Canada are eligible to participate in the Stock Appreciation Rights Plan (the &#147;<B>SAR Plan</B>&#148;), pursuant to which the Corporation may grant stand-alone SARs. The Corporation may grant SARs at the closing price of the Common Shares on the day preceding the grant. Vesting of SARs is determined by the Board at the time of grant; although SARs generally vest in 25% increments over four years and expire ten years after the date of grant. <BR><BR>See <B>Schedule &#147;E&#148; </B>for a detailed description of the SAR Plan.</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Attract and Retain<BR>
    <BR>
    Motivate<BR>
    <BR>
    Align executive and Shareholder interests
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Competitive SAR grants ensure access to talented employees necessary to achieve corporate objectives. <BR><BR>Motivates employees to achieve corporate goals and improve value of Common Shares, as SARs gain value only if share price increases over grant price. <BR><BR>Encourages sustained, long-term growth by linking portion of compensation to long-term company performance.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD colspan="3" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -7pt; margin-left: 7pt">
    <B>Performance Share Units</B>
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Senior executives (including NEOs) and key employees are eligible to participate in either the Performance Share Unit Plan for Canadian employees (the &#147;<B>Canadian PSU Plan</B>&#148;) or the Performance Share Unit Plan for U.S. employees (the &#147;<B>U.S. PSU Plan</B>&#148; and, collectively with the Canadian PSU Plan, the &#147;<B>PSU Plan</B>&#148;), pursuant to which the Corporation may grant performance share units (&#147;<B>PSUs</B>&#148;). The value of a PSU is tied to the value of the Common Shares, based on the price of Common Shares on the NYSE. The grant of a PSU will entitle the employee to the right to receive a cash payment equal to the market value of the PSU at the completion of a three-year performance period.<BR><BR>PSUs (including dividend equivalent performance share units) vest at the end of a three-year performance cycle beginning on January 1 of the grant year and ending on December 31 three years thereafter. The number of units that vest depends on the relative ranking of the Cor
poration&#146;s total shareholder return (&#147;<B>Total Shareholder Return</B>&#148;) over the three-year performance cycle compared to the Total Shareholder Return over the same period for a selected peer group of companies. One hundred percent of the PSUs vest if the Corporation&#146;s Total Shareholder Return is equal to the median of the peer group. Vesting ranges between 50% for performance at or below the 25th&#160;percentile and up to 150% for performance at or above the 75th&#160;percentile. If the Corporation&#146;s Total Shareholder Return is negative over a three-year performance cycle, the percentage of PSUs that vest may not exceed 100%. No PSUs vest if, over the three-year performance cycle, the Corporation&#146;s Total Shareholder Return is both negative and falls below the 25th&#160;percentile of the selected peer group of companies.<BR><BR>The peer group for purposes of PSUs is comprised of a select sample of comparably-sized, publicly traded North American chemical and fertilizer companies
. See &#147;Basis for Compensation Decisions - Peer Groups&#148; (below) for details with respect to the PSU Peer Group.<BR><BR>See <B>Schedule &#147;E&#148; </B>for a detailed description of the PSU Plan.</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Motivate and Reward <BR>
    <BR>
    Align executive and Shareholder interests
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
<DIV style="text-indent: -0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
Encourages medium-term growth by linking portion of compensation to medium-term company performance. <BR><BR>Vesting of PSUs is linked to the achievement of Shareholder return objectives over future performance periods.
</DIV>
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" valign="top">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom" style="font-size: 1pt">
<TD colspan="7" style="border-top: 1px solid #000000">
&nbsp;
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <B>Note:</B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 3pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="2%"></TD>
    <TD width="98%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 8pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>    (1)&#160;</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    The compensation plans discussed in the above table are those
    plans which apply to senior executives of Agrium. Please note
    that Agrium has additional compensation plans in place which are
    designed to motivate and reward non-executive employee groups.
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Illustration
    of Compensation Mix</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Agrium&#146;s executive compensation program is designed to
    inspire our executives to strive for superior performance and to
    ensure that a greater percentage of compensation is performance
    based (or &#147;at-risk&#148;) for executives who bear higher
    levels of responsibility. The following table shows the target
    compensation mix for 2009:

    43
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<A name='155'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Compensation
    Process</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Compensation reflects an employee&#146;s value to Agrium&#146;s
    business, including the market value of the skills the employee
    brings to the business, the value of the employee&#146;s
    individual contribution and the business results that are
    generated as a result of employee efforts. In order to ensure
    that Agrium appropriately assesses and compensates senior
    executives, Agrium uses the following compensation process:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <IMG src="o59476o5947673.gif" alt="(FLOW CHART)">
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Persons
    Involved in Compensation Process</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Board has responsibility for overseeing Agrium&#146;s
    compensation program. As is set out in &#147;Section&#160;Three:
    Corporate Governance&#160;&#151; Human Resources&#160;&#038;
    Compensation Committee&#148; (above), the Board has delegated
    certain oversight responsibilities to the HR&#038;C Committee,
    but retains final authority over some aspects of the
    compensation program and process. This authority includes
    approval of material amendments to or adoption of new
    equity-based compensation plans and review and approval of
    HR&#038;C Committee recommendations regarding executive
    compensation.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In designing the various elements and determining amounts of
    compensation, the HR&#038;C Committee draws upon the expertise
    of the Chair of the HR&#038;C Committee, the CEO and the Senior
    Human Resources Officer and confers with Agrium&#146;s Chief
    Legal Officer and CFO on matters that fall within their
    respective realms of responsibility.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Agrium&#146;s Senior Human Resources Officer provides the
    HR&#038;C Committee with internal and external analyses
    regarding the basic structure and competitiveness of
    Agrium&#146;s compensation program and the details of
    Agrium&#146;s various compensation and incentive plans. Each
    year, the Senior Human Resources Officer also provides the
    Committee with a detailed review of the estimated and actual
    results for each performance measure compared to threshold,
    target and maximum goals and the resulting estimated and actual
    payments to the executive officers. The HR&#038;C
    Committee&#146;s interactions with the Senior Human Resources
    Officer include at least one meeting in which no other members
    of management are present.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Agrium relies on its compensation consultant, Towers Watson, to
    assist it in various aspects of the compensation process. The
    assistance provided by the consultant in 2009 included:
    (i)&#160;assisting the HR&#038;C Committee in updating and
    evaluating the appropriateness of the peer companies that it
    uses to evaluate the competitiveness of Agrium&#146;s executive
    compensation program; (ii)&#160;undertaking competitive reviews
    of senior executive and Board of
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    44
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Director compensation levels; (iii)&#160;supporting the
    HR&#038;C Committee in the review of material and
    recommendations that are originated by management;
    (iv)&#160;providing information on trends in compensation design
    to the HR&#038;C Committee and the Human Resources Department;
    and (v)&#160;assisting the Human Resources Department with
    changes to the design of the compensation program. In addition,
    Towers Watson undertakes a forward-looking&#160;and look-back
    analysis of compensation paid to select NEOs on the request of
    the HR&#038;C Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    A senior representative of Towers Watson met with the full Board
    and participated in portions of three (out of four) HR&#038;C
    Committee meetings in 2009. During those meetings, the HR&#038;C
    Committee met with the Towers Watson representative without the
    CEO or members of management present. In the course of preparing
    for those meetings, the Towers Watson representative conferred
    with the HR&#038;C Committee Chair and the Senior Human
    Resources Officer.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Determining
    Compensation Mix</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    On an annual basis, the HR&#038;C Committee reviews
    Agrium&#146;s executive compensation program, including the mix
    of compensation offered and the appropriateness of short, medium
    and long-term performance-based opportunities. The CEO and the
    Senior Human Resources Officer advise the HR&#038;C Committee
    regarding the competitiveness of the compensation program and
    their impact on Agrium&#146;s ability to attract, motivate and
    retain talented employees and executives. In addition, the
    HR&#038;C Committee reviews information about the compensation
    programs of peer group companies, with whom Agrium competes for
    human resources. Peer group information is used to set target
    level compensation for Agrium executives. See &#147;Basis for
    Compensation Decisions&#160;&#151; Peer Groups&#148; (below) for
    more information regarding the selection of Agrium&#146;s peer
    groups.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The design and administration of specific elements of
    compensation is the responsibility of Agrium&#146;s Human
    Resources Department, with input and approval, where necessary,
    from the HR&#038;C Committee and with the assistance of the
    compensation consultant. Typically, strategic decisions on the
    compensation program are considered by the HR&#038;C Committee
    over the course of more than one meeting before final approval
    is given.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Setting
    Performance Objectives and Goals</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The CEO, in consultation with the Board and senior management,
    is responsible for developing the Corporation&#146;s overall
    strategic plan. On the basis of the strategic plan, the CEO
    develops an annual business plan and sets out proposed corporate
    goals, strategies and objectives, which are reviewed and
    approved by the Board. In February of each year, the CEO, the
    Chair of the Board and the Chair of the HR&#038;C Committee meet
    and establish compensation objectives, which are linked to the
    Corporation&#146;s strategic and annual business plans. These
    objectives include both general corporate and financial
    objectives used to assess performance for the purpose of annual
    incentive compensation of senior management and individual
    performance criteria that will be used to assess the performance
    of the CEO. In some circumstances, the compensation objectives
    may diverge from the Corporation&#146;s strategic and annual
    business plans, and the HR&#038;C Committee specifically
    discusses and considers the merits of and the reasons for any
    such divergence. The final corporate and CEO performance
    objectives are approved by the HR&#038;C Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The CEO meets with Agrium&#146;s senior executives and the
    Senior Human Resources Officer to discuss the specific
    objectives that have been set. The senior executives, in
    consultation with the CEO, set individual performance
    objectives, which are linked to the Corporation&#146;s strategic
    plan, annual business plan and corporate goals. The CEO advises
    the HR&#038;C Committee regarding senior executives&#146;
    objectives and discusses the alignment of the objectives with
    overall strategy.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Reviewing
    Performance and Setting Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    One of the HR&#038;C Committee&#146;s most important
    responsibilities is making recommendations to the Board
    regarding the CEO&#146;s compensation. In making these
    recommendations, the HR&#038;C Committee evaluates the
    CEO&#146;s performance, including discussion of the
    Corporation&#146;s performance relative to corporate objectives
    and strategic and annual business plans and the CEO&#146;s
    individual performance relative to individual goals. The
    HR&#038;C Committee reviews the various elements of the
    CEO&#146;s compensation in the context of the total compensation
    package (including salary, annual cash incentive awards,
    long-term equity incentive awards (including prior awards
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    45
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    under equity compensation plans) and accrued pension benefits)
    and recommends a compensation package. The HR&#038;C
    Committee&#146;s recommendations regarding the CEO&#146;s
    compensation are presented to the independent members of the
    Board, who together determine the CEO&#146;s compensation and
    provide feedback and recommendations in connection with his
    performance evaluation. These recommendations are then reviewed
    with the CEO by the Board Chair and the Chair of the HR&#038;C
    Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee consults with the CEO in regard to his
    evaluation of the performance of the executives who report to
    him. The CEO makes recommendations to the HR&#038;C Committee
    regarding executive merit increases, incentive compensation and
    total compensation for executives being hired or promoted. As
    part of the compensation process, the HR&#038;C Committee
    assesses the compensation awarded to the senior executive team
    to ensure that there is appropriate internal equity between
    members of the executive team, such that employees with similar
    responsibilities, experience and historical performance are
    rewarded comparably. The HR&#038;C Committee annually reviews
    total compensation tables prepared by management and the
    consultant for each NEO. A report is also prepared periodically
    to (i)&#160;describe trends in termination and change of control
    provisions, (ii)&#160;review current provisions applicable to
    Agrium&#146;s senior executives under executive employment
    agreements and (iii)&#160;review potential aggregate and
    incremental payment upon employment termination or change of
    control. The overall purpose of these tables and this report is
    to aggregate on a uniform basis all of the elements of actual
    and potential executive compensation upon termination and assist
    the HR&#038;C Committee to review the elements of NEO
    compensation in the context of the total compensation package.
    The HR&#038;C Committee&#146;s recommendations regarding the
    NEOs&#146; compensation are presented to the Board, which
    determines the NEOs&#146; compensation and provides feedback and
    recommendations in connection with their performance.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Perks,
    Benefits and Pension Arrangements</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The perks, benefits and pension arrangements offered by the
    Corporation were designed to be competitive with those of
    comparable peer companies and are periodically reviewed by the
    HR&#038;C Committee to ensure that they remain so. In addition,
    specific changes to perks, benefits and pension arrangements may
    be submitted to the HR&#038;C Committee for its consideration by
    the compensation consultant or management in circumstances where
    such persons become aware of changes to standard industry
    practices.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Reimbursement
    of Annual and Long-Term Incentive Compensation (Clawback
    Policy)</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In February 2010, the Board of Directors adopted an executive
    compensation clawback policy concerning future awards made under
    the Corporation&#146;s annual and long-term incentive plans. The
    policy applies to all executive officers. In situations where:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="92%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    (i)&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the amount of incentive compensation received by the executive
    or former executive officer was calculated based upon, or
    contingent on, the achievement of certain financial results that
    were subsequently the subject of or affected by a material
    restatement of all or a portion of the Corporation&#146;s
    financial statements;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    (ii)&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the executive or former executive officer engaged in intentional
    misconduct or fraud that caused or partially caused the need for
    the restatement, as admitted by the executive officer or, in the
    absence of such admission, as determined by a court of competent
    jurisdiction in a final judgment that cannot be
    appealed;&#160;and
</TD>
</TR>


<TR style="line-height: 6pt; font-size: 1pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>


<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>    (iii)&#160;
</TD>
    <TD align="left">
    the amount of compensation payment received would have been
    lower had the financial results been properly reported;
</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    then the Board may, to the full extent permitted by applicable
    laws and to the extent it determines that it is in the
    Corporation&#146;s best interest to do so, require reimbursement
    (up to the amount by which the incentive compensation received
    by such executive officer exceeded that which the executive
    officer would have received had the financial results been
    properly reported) of all or a portion of incentive compensation
    received by an executive officer made under the
    Corporation&#146;s annual and long-term incentive compensation
    plans.
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    46
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Succession
    Planning for the CEO and Management</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The Corporation has a formal management succession planning
    process. Pursuant to this process, the Board and the HR&#038;C
    Committee are responsible for reviewing and approving succession
    plans for the CEO and other members of senior management. This
    includes managing, tracking and evaluating leadership
    development and succession. Agrium&#146;s succession process
    ensures that suitable candidates are identified and receive
    appropriate development opportunities and exposure to corporate
    values. The CEO is actively involved in developing preliminary
    plans for his succession. The Board is responsible for approving
    the management succession plan for the CEO and the HR&#038;C
    Committee reviews and approves a succession planning report,
    including the identification and development of CEO and other
    officer succession candidates, annually. The management
    succession process includes a process that would respond to an
    emergency situation which required an immediate replacement of
    the incumbent CEO.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Granting
    of Equity Awards</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Typically, the Board grants equity awards of stock options, SARs
    and PSUs on an annual basis at its February meeting, based on
    the recommendations of the HR&#038;C Committee. By making these
    awards at the time it is reviewing performance, the Board and
    the HR&#038;C Committee are able to balance the elements of core
    compensation and align compensation with the Corporation&#146;s
    business strategy. In determining the type and amount of any
    equity grant, the HR&#038;C Committee considers previous grants
    made, including awards which remain unvested
    <FONT style="white-space: nowrap">and/or</FONT>
    unexercised. In addition, the Corporation has a
    &#147;<B>President&#146;s Award Program</B>&#148; pursuant to
    which, under a delegation of authority by the Board to the
    President&#160;&#038; Chief Executive Officer, the CEO may grant
    awards of stock options and SARs to eligible employees in
    connection with exceptionally meritorious performance,
    promotions and new hires. The President&#146;s Award Program is
    limited as to the aggregate number of stock options and SARs
    that may be awarded thereunder. Since the inception of the
    Program in 1998, there have been an aggregate of 300,000 stock
    options and SARs authorized. An aggregate of 293,300 stock
    options have been granted under the Program, of which 176,775
    have been exercised, and 26,625 have been cancelled (and
    returned to the pool available for future grants), leaving an
    aggregate balance of 33,325 stock options and SARs available to
    be granted. The Program was amended in 2006 to authorize an
    additional aggregate number outstanding at any time of up to
    20,000 PSUs which may be made available and awarded to eligible
    employees under the Program.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In February 2009, the Corporation adopted an explicit policy
    (the &#147;<B>Option Granting Policy</B>&#148;) to document the
    Corporation&#146;s practices and promote the consistent and
    efficient administration of stock options and SARs, including
    (i)&#160;the procedure for annual grants, (ii)&#160;the
    procedure for one-off grants under the President&#146;s Award
    Program, (iii)&#160;meticulous record keeping, and (iv)&#160;the
    postponement of grants if non-public material information exists
    at the time of any proposed grant.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The total number of Common Shares reserved for issuance pursuant
    to the Stock Option Plan shall not exceed 13,650,625 Common
    Shares unless any increase is authorized by the Shareholders of
    the Corporation. As of the date of this Circular, the maximum
    number of Common Shares that remain available for future option
    grants under the Stock Option Plan is 830,910&#160;Common Shares
    (representing 0.5% of the Common Shares which were outstanding
    as of the date of this Circular). The maximum number of Common
    Shares subject to outstanding options is 2,960,087&#160;Common
    Shares (representing 2% of the outstanding Common Shares). In
    2009, 517,100&#160;stock options were granted, which represent
    0.3% of the total number of Common Shares outstanding on a fully
    diluted basis as at December&#160;31, 2009. Common Shares
    underlying options that are not exercised or that are terminated
    on the exercise of connected SARs shall again be available for
    subsequent option grant under the Stock Option Plan.
</DIV>

<A name='156'>
<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Basis for
    Compensation Decisions</FONT></B>
</DIV>
</A>
<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Peer
    Groups</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    Target compensation levels for Agrium executives are set at the
    median of comparator peer groups. The peer group for
    Agrium&#146;s CEO, CFO and Business Unit Presidents consists of
    U.S.&#160;based chemical and fertilizer companies (the
    &#147;<B>U.S.&#160;Peer Group</B>&#148;) because the competitive
    talent pool for individuals in these positions is largely
    U.S.&#160;based. For other corporate leadership positions,
    including all Senior Vice Presidents and other executive level
    positions, the peer group consists of a 50%/50% blend of
    U.S.&#160;chemical peer companies and a select sample of
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    47
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="width: 87%; margin-left: 6%"><!-- BEGIN PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    comparably sized Canadian companies from a range of industrial
    sectors (the &#147;<B>Mixed Peer Group</B>&#148;). The following
    table provides an overview of the 2009 U.S.&#160;Peer Group and
    Mixed Peer Group as compared to the
    Corporation<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">(1)</SUP>:

</DIV>

    <TD align="right" valign="top">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">(1)
    </FONT></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD valign="bottom">
    <FONT style="font-size: 8pt">Agrium reports its financial
    results in U.S. dollars. Information concerning peer group
    companies reporting in Canadian dollars has been converted at a
    rate of U.S.$1.00 = Cdn.$1.1420, the average annual exchange
    rate for 2009. Market capitalization has been converted from
    Cdn.$ to U.S.$ using the exchange rate on December&#160;31, 2009
    of U.S.$1.00 = Cdn.$1.0466.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee, in consultation with its compensation
    consultant, reviews the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer
    Group annually to ensure that they continue to be appropriate.
    The peer groups were last reviewed on December&#160;10, 2009, at
    which time the HR&#038;C Committee approved minor amendments to
    both peer groups. The amended peer groups were used to evaluate
    executive compensation at the completion of fiscal 2009. The
    criteria used for determining the companies included in the peer
    groups include that each company is (i)&#160;autonomous and
    publicly-traded, (ii)&#160;has comparable revenues to that of
    Agrium, (iii)&#160;in the chemicals industry for the
    U.S.&#160;Peer Group and a capital intensive business (e.g.
    chemicals, energy services, forest products, industrial
    manufacturing, mining and oil&#160;&#038; gas) for the Mixed
    Peer Group, (iv)&#160;is similarly sized considering assets,
    market capitalization and number of employees, and (v)&#160;has
    robust compensation data available.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    In addition to the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group,
    Agrium uses a designated group of competitors (the &#147;<B>PSU
    Peer Group</B>&#148;) against which it measures its Total
    Shareholder Return for the purpose of PSU performance vesting.
    The PSU Peer Group has been chosen by the HR&#038;C Committee as
    an appropriate comparator group for measuring total shareholder
    return, as it is representative of investment opportunities for
    equity investors seeking exposure to our industrial sector. Some
    of the members of the PSU Peer Group are included in either one
    or both of the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group;
    however, the U.S.&#160;Peer Group and Mixed Peer Group are
    broader than
</DIV>
<!-- XBRL Paragraph Pagebreak -->
<!-- XBRL Pagebreak Begin -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    <BR>
    48
</DIV><!-- END PAGE WIDTH -->
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<!-- XBRL Pagebreak End -->

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    the PSU Peer Group as they include a range of companies against
    which Agrium competes for executive talent but which may not be
    appropriate for comparing shareholder returns. The members of
    the PSU Peer Group are:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The HR&#038;C Committee, in consultation with its compensation
    consultant, reviews and updates the PSU Peer Group at least
    bi-annually to ensure that it continues to be appropriate. The
    PSU Peer Group was last updated on December&#160;10, 2009.
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 12pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 2%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: Arial, Helvetica; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">

    <B><I><FONT style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times">Target
    Level&#160;Compensation</FONT></I></B>
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt; font-size: 1pt">&nbsp;</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; margin-right: 0%; text-indent: 4%; font-size: 10pt; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times; color: #000000; background: #FFFFFF">
    The table below sets out (i)&#160;the target level of
    compensation for NEOs assuming desired performance and
    achievement of goals, and (ii)&#160;the manner in which actual
    compensation can vary from the targeted level of compensation.
</DIV>

    companies.

    specifics on base salary determinations.

    award was 5% of base salary.<BR>

    &#147;<B>Maximum</B>&#148; award.  In 2009, the Maximum award
    level was 10% of base salary.

<DIV style="text-indent: -8pt; margin-left: 8pt">
    Stock Options, SARs&#160;&#038; PSUs
</DIV>
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    The targeted expected value of grants is near the
    50<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">th</SUP>&#160;percentile

    (median) of the value of target long-term incentives among  the
    U.S. Peer Group or Mixed Peer Group (as applicable) by level.
</TD>
<TD>
&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD align="left" valign="top">
    Individual grants can be higher or lower and will reflect the
    level of sustained contribution of each executive.<BR>
    <BR>
    In addition, the number of PSUs that vest is performance based
    and additional PSUs may be awarded based on relative Total
    Shareholder Return performance (maximum increase in award is
    150% if Total Shareholder Return is at
    75<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top">th</SUP>&#160;percentile

    or better).
</TD>
</TR>
<TR valign="bottom">
<TD nowrap align="left" valign="top">

    specifics on long-term incentive compensation determinations.
</TD>
